Author: falsestprophet
Content: There are a lot of cool computationally intensive problems in drug design/discovery and trading/investing. There is also the possibility of a substantial upside in both fields.

Author: abstractbill
Content: I learned Lisp aged 12, after messing around a bit with Basic. I consider myself very lucky for having had that experience. Writing an ELIZA clone at that age was a lot of fun - I remember in particular thinking it was hilarious to give my version a very rude personality ;-)

Author: Harj
Content:
"They took VC money when they have paying customers and a working business model and it was time to grow the company."

Paypal had no idea what their business model was going to be when they took VC (they tried to fight off ebay sellers to begin with), their idea changed every week. They actually raised money so they could buy users (literally, they gave users money if they signed up).

"entrepreneurs should concentrate on building their company with their own money FIRST"

it's precisely because this isn't an option for young founders out of college that something like YC exists. we have no money of our own in the first place so taking external investment is our only option.

Author: jamiequint
Content: For my consulting business I had Bank of America Small Business account and used Quickbooks a little bit, but mostly did ad hoc accounting.

Author: curi
Content:
I agree that understanding why is important, but I don't think having some silly comments prevents that.

Though in this case, what interests me more than why France is primitive, is why we are better. Which part of our traditions prevents us from having this law?

While I have general answers to that question, I don't have any answers specific to this particular law.

Edit: BTW my comment did allude to a serious answer. They have a different meaning of freedom in France, and are somewhat hostile to our meaning of it.

Author: falsestprophet
Content:
Just get a no-fee business checking account at a convenient bank with a debit card, once you are making or spending a lot of money you can shop around for something that suits you better.

I use Fifth Third.

Author: davidw
Content:
Hacker news should always be about trying to understand why things work the way they do, even if we view them as misguided.

A lot of European countries look askance at "cutthroat" competition:

http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story...

Perhaps the idea is that in some cases, with too much undercutting, a single monopolistic vendor might be able to emerge, having killed off the competition. Which to me seems like a terrible reason to keep laws like this around - worry about the monopoly when it actually happens, and otherwise let the market get on with things.

Author: henning
Content: No. The only startups that exist are JavaScript hacks that take up 90 MB of RAM.

Author: rob
Title: Hacker News RSS 'comment' link is messed up
Content:
It seems the node in the RSS feed is missing a slash after the '.com' part. For example, it's showing up as 'http://news.ycombinator.comitem?id=101355'.

Does everyone else have the same problem? I'm using NetNewsWire.

Content: It is amazing that Yahoo has yet to copy Adsense, I mean they know is giving billons to Google, and you wait years and have not even complete a decent copy of it???

Author: ivankirigin
Content:
Indeed. But ultra portable approaches the mobile space. I suppose with the meteoric rise of celltop and ultra portables, it should be a more prominent issue. It's interesting to think that the average pixel count might actually decrease.

My celltop has zoom but the best sites just have another version for it.

2007 was the first year that more laptops than desktops were sold. If you consider browser enabled cellphones, I wonder how those numbers change.

Author: cosmok
Content: personalized search can be good (for both Google and you), but , involves some pretty serious privacy concerns. I would rather use something like this: http://history.sansj.com where all data stays in my server.
